choices.text: Repeat fasting blood sugar (FBS) for 3 days
Do a 3 AM blood glucose check
Increase evening/night time insulin dose
Reduce carbohydrate intake in meals

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 1 diabetes on insulin therapy reports waking up with high blood glucose levels despite going to bed with normal readings. Which of the following would be most helpful in determining the cause of the morning hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Do a 3 AM blood glucose check

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms could be due to either the Somogyi effect or the dawn phenomenon:

 

  • Somogyi effect: Nocturnal hypoglycemia triggers a counter-regulatory hormone release, leading to rebound hyperglycemia in the morning.
  • Dawn phenomenon: Normal hormonal changes in the early morning hours lead to increased insulin resistance and elevated blood glucose.

 

A 3 AM blood glucose check can help differentiate between these two conditions:

 

  • Hypoglycemia at 3 AM: Suggests the Somogyi effect.
  • Normal or elevated glucose at 3 AM: Suggests the dawn phenomenon.

 

Identifying the underlying cause is crucial for appropriate treatment adjustments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Repeat FBS for 3 days: While useful for assessing overall glycemic control, it won't pinpoint the cause of the morning hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Increase evening/night time insulin dose: This might be appropriate if the dawn phenomenon is confirmed, but it could worsen hypoglycemia if the Somogyi effect is the cause.

 

Option D. Reduce carbohydrate intake in meals: This could help manage overall blood sugar levels but may not address the specific issue of morning hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 3 AM blood glucose check helps differentiate between the Somogyi effect (nocturnal hypoglycemia) and the dawn phenomenon (early morning insulin resistance).

questions.text: Which of the following is essential for calculating insulin dose prior to a meal in type 1 diabetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin to carbohydrate ratio

 

Option C:

 

The insulin to carbohydrate ratio (I:C ratio) is the most essential factor for calculating the insulin dose for a meal in type 1 diabetes. It represents the number of grams of carbohydrates covered by one unit of insulin. By knowing the I:C ratio and the amount of carbohydrates in a meal, the patient can calculate the appropriate insulin dose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycemic index: While the glycemic index provides information about how quickly a food raises blood sugar, it is not directly used in calculating the insulin dose.

 

Option B. Glycemic load: Glycemic load combines the glycemic index with the amount of carbohydrate in a food. It can be helpful in meal planning, but the I:C ratio is the primary tool for calculating the insulin dose.

 

Option D. Preprandial blood glucose values: While important for determining the need for a correction dose of insulin, preprandial blood glucose values alone are not sufficient to calculate the mealtime insulin dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insulin to carbohydrate ratio is essential for calculating the insulin dose for a meal in type 1 diabetes.

choices.text: Avoid carbohydrates for the day
Recheck CBG the next day

questions.text: A 21-year-old professional gym trainer who is a known type 1 diabetic is about to start a training session. Just before the session, he notices his capillary blood glucose (CBG) to be 280 mg/dL. What should he do?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Check ketones

 

Option A:

 

A CBG of 280 mg/dL indicates significant hyperglycemia, which can be dangerous for people with type 1 diabetes. Before exercising, it is essential to check for ketones. The presence of ketones indicates that the body is breaking down fat for energy due to insufficient insulin, and this can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious condition. If ketones are present, the individual should not exercise and seek medical attention immediately.

 

Glycemic management during exercise:

 

  • CBG < 90 mg/dL: Ingest 15 to 30 g of glucose before starting exercise. Delay exercise until blood glucose is 90 mg/dL and monitor closely for hypoglycaemia.
  • CBG 90 to 125 mg/dL: Ingest 10 g of glucose before starting aerobic exercise. Anaerobic exercise and high intensity interval training sessions can be started.
  • CBG 126 to 250 mg/dL: Aerobic exercise can be started.
  • Anaerobic exercise can be started, but glucose concentrations could rise.
  • CBG > 250 mg/dL: Check ketones.
  • Ketones < 0·6 mmol/L: Mild-to-moderate aerobic exercise can be started
  • Ketones 0.6- 1·4 mmol/L: Exercise should be restricted to a light intensity for only a brief duration (<30 min) and a small corrective insulin dose might be needed.
  • Ketones ≥1.5 mmol/L: Exercise is contraindicated and glucose management should be initiated rapidly as per the advice of the healthcare professional team.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inject insulin and exercise: Injecting insulin before exercise could lead to hypoglycemia during the workout, which can be dangerous.

 

Option C. Avoid carbohydrates for the day: This could also lead to hypoglycemia as carbohydrates are the primary source of energy for the body.

 

Option D. Recheck CBG the next day: Delaying action on elevated blood sugar levels is not recommended and could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Check for ketones before exercising if blood glucose levels are above 250 mg/dL to prevent the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old diabetic patient presents with breathlessness to the emergency department. On evaluation, the patient's ejection fraction (EF) is 35%. Which of the following medications should be avoided for the treatment of diabetes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pioglitazone

 

Option C:

 

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione (TZD), is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic heart failure due to its potential to worsen fluid retention and exacerbate heart failure. A reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 35% indicates systolic heart failure, making pioglitazone an inappropriate choice for this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor): Empagliflozin has been shown to have cardioprotective effects and can be beneficial in patients with heart failure.

 

Option B. Dulaglutide (GLP-1 receptor agonist): GLP-1 receptor agonists like dulaglutide have shown cardiovascular benefits and may be considered in patients with heart failure.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin (DPP-4 inhibitor): DPP-4 inhibitors are generally safe in patients with heart failure and do not have significant negative effects on cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid pioglitazone in patients with symptomatic heart failure due to the risk of fluid retention and exacerbation of heart failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes on insulin was recently started on a new drug. After a week, she presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, near-normal blood glucose, elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, and elevated plasma ketones. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA), a rare but serious complication of diabetes. While DKA is typically associated with high blood glucose levels, euDKA occurs with near-normal or even low blood glucose.

 

Canagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is known to increase the risk of euDKA. It works by increasing urinary glucose excretion, which can lead to a relative deficit of glucose available for energy. This can trigger the body to break down fat for fuel, producing ketones and leading to acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis but not associated with euDKA.

 

Option C. Semaglutide: Semaglutide (a GLP-1 receptor agonist) is not associated with euDKA.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone (a thiazolidinedione) is not known to cause euDKA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA).

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presents with a 3-month history of 7 kg weight loss despite increased appetite and nocturia. Lab reports showed a fasting blood sugar (FBS) of 331 mg/dL and an HbA1c of 11.2%. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Insulin Glargine

 

Option D:

 

The patient presents with significant hyperglycemia (elevated FBS and HbA1c) along with classic symptoms of diabetes (weight loss, polyuria, polydipsia). This presentation, combined with the rapid weight loss, suggests a new-onset type 1 or ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus.

 

  • Insulin is recommended as the first injectable in patients who are having severe hyperglycemia (FBS > 300 or A1C > 10%) and/or those who are symptomatic (like in this case).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line agent for type 2 diabetes, it is not appropriate for initial therapy in patients with severe hyperglycemia or those suspected of having type 1 diabetes due to the risk of lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, promoting insulin release and decreasing glucagon secretion. It is not potent enough to manage the severe hyperglycemia in this patient.

 

Option C. Empagliflozin: This is an SGLT2 inhibitor that increases urinary glucose excretion. While it can help lower blood sugar, it can also increase the risk of euglycemic DKA, especially in patients with significant hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is recommended for patients with severe hyperglycemia (FBS > 300 or A1C > 10%) and/or those who are symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for vigorous exercise in individuals with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proliferative retinopathy

 

Option A:

 

Proliferative retinopathy is a severe form of diabetic eye disease characterized by the growth of new blood vessels in the retina. These vessels are fragile and prone to bleeding, which can lead to vision loss. Vigorous exercise can increase the risk of bleeding in the eye and potentially worsen retinopathy. Therefore, it is a contraindication for strenuous physical activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. ESRD (End-Stage Renal Disease): While exercise should be adjusted based on kidney function and individual tolerance, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Neuropathy: Exercise is generally encouraged in patients with diabetic neuropathy, as it can help improve nerve function and reduce pain. However, certain types of exercise may need to be modified based on the severity of neuropathy.

 

Option D. Peripheral arterial disease (PAD): Exercise can actually be beneficial for PAD as it improves circulation and reduces symptoms. However, the intensity and duration should be adjusted based on the severity of PAD and the individual's tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigorous exercise is contraindicated in individuals with proliferative retinopathy due to the risk of retinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity presents to the clinic. She is currently taking metformin 1000 mg twice daily, but her glycemic control remains suboptimal (HbA1c 8.5%). She is interested in a medication that can help with both weight loss and glucose control. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tirzepatide

 

Option D:

 

Tirzepatide is a dual glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) and glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, making it a suitable option for patients with type 2 diabetes who need both improved glycemic control and weight loss. It has been shown to be more effective than other GLP-1 receptor agonists in achieving these goals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Liraglutide, Option B. Dulaglutide and Option C. Semaglutide: While these GLP-1 receptor agonists can promote weight loss and improve glycemic control, tirzepatide has shown superior efficacy in clinical trials compared to these options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tirzepatide, a dual GIP and GLP-1 receptor agonist, is highly effective for both glycemic control and weight loss in type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metreleptin

 

Option D:

 

Metreleptin is a recombinant human leptin analog used to treat generalized lipodystrophy, not specifically HIV-associated lipodystrophy (HALS). HALS is a distinct form of lipodystrophy characterized by fat redistribution, often involving loss of subcutaneous fat in the face, limbs, and buttocks, and accumulation of visceral fat in the abdomen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: Can reduce abdominal fat in HALS.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Can be used to treat lipoatrophy and hepatic steatosis in HALS.

 

Option C. Tesamorelin: A growth hormone-releasing hormone analog that helps reduce excess abdominal fat in HALS (but IGF-1 should be monitored).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metreleptin is used to treat generalized lipodystrophy and is not specifically used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following preparations of insulin has the longest time to onset and the longest duration of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glargine

 

Option B:

 

Glargine is a long-acting insulin analog designed to provide a basal level of insulin over an extended period. It has a slow onset of action (1-2 hours) and a prolonged duration of action (20-24 hours), making it suitable for providing consistent background insulin levels throughout the day.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspart: This is a rapid-acting insulin analog with a quick onset (15-30 minutes) and short duration (3-5 hours).

 

Option C. NPH: This is an intermediate-acting insulin with a slower onset (1-2 hours) and moderate duration (12-18 hours).

 

Option D. Regular: This is a short-acting insulin with a relatively quick onset (30-60 minutes) and shorter duration (5-8 hours).

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glargine is a long-acting insulin analog with a slow onset (1-2 hours) and prolonged duration (20-24 hours).

choices.text: Inject insulin at the same site every day.
Evening NPH insulin is preferably injected in the abdomen.
Regular insulin is preferably injected in the legs/arms.
Cleaning the injection site with an alcohol swab is not necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding insulin injection is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cleaning the injection site with an alcohol swab is not necessary.

 

Option D:

 

While cleaning the injection site with an alcohol swab is a common practice, it is not necessary for routine insulin injections. If the skin is visibly clean and dry - disinfecting with alcohol does not reduce the risk of infection and may cause unnecessary discomfort. However, if the skin is dirty, it is recommended to clean it with soap and water before injection. Recommendations for insulin -

 

  • Insulin can be injected into the abdominal wall, leg, arm, or buttock.
  • Human insulins are absorbed fastest from the abdominal wall, slowest from the leg and buttock, and at an intermediate rate from the arm. These differences can be useful clinically:
  • Pre-meal regular insulin should be rapidly absorbed, and injection into the abdominal wall may therefore be preferable.
  • Pre-evening meal dosing of NPH should be slowly absorbed to ensure a duration of action that lasts through the night, and injection in the leg or buttock may be preferable.
  • The absorption of the long-acting basal insulin analogs, glargine and degludec, do not appear to be significantly influenced by injection site.
  • Do not expose insulin to extremes of temperature.
  • Efficacy of some insulins (especially intermediate and long acting forms) may decrease > 30 days. Refrigerate (DO NOT FREEZE) insulin vials between injections.
  • If using pens – recommendations vary based on the manufacturer. Unopened pens can be stored in refrigerator and one opened pens can be kept at room temperature for 14-28 days.
  • Premix insulins lose potency more quickly than others.
  • Shallow injections result in pain whereas inadvertent deeper (IM) injections can result in erratic/rapid absorption. Most injections are given at 900 angle with skin pinched/lifted.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inject insulin at the same site every day: This is incorrect. Rotating injection sites within a body area is important to prevent lipodystrophy, which can affect insulin absorption.

 

Option B. Evening NPH is preferably injected in the abdomen: Pre-evening meal dosing of NPH should be slowly absorbed to ensure a duration of action that lasts through the night, and injection in the leg or buttock may be preferable.

 

Option C. Regular insulin is preferably injected in the legs/buttocks: Pre-meal regular insulin should be rapidly absorbed, and injection into the abdominal wall may therefore be preferable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine cleaning of the insulin injection site with an alcohol swab is not necessary if the skin is visibly clean and dry.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman on metformin (MF) cannot achieve glycemic control. She has had a previous osteoporotic fracture and does not want injectable medications. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Semaglutide

 

Option D:

 

While Semaglutide is primarily available as an injectable medication, it is now also available in oral form. It is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that promotes weight loss and improves glycemic control. It is a suitable option for this patient as it addresses both her uncontrolled diabetes and obesity, and it's available in a non-injectable form.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: DPP-4 inhibitor, not associated with significant weight loss.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Thiazolidinedione, associated with weight gain and increased fracture risk, contraindicated in this patient.

 

Option C. Canagliflozin: SGLT2 inhibitor, while it promotes weight loss, it has been associated with increased fracture risk in some studies, making it less suitable for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Semaglutide is available in oral form and is suitable for obese diabetic patients seeking non-injectable medications that promote weight loss and improve glycemic control.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and coronary artery disease (CAD) has an HbA1c of 8.2% despite metformin and glimepiride therapy. She has a history of recurrent hypoglycemia and is concerned about weight gain. Which of the following medications would be the most appropriate addition to her regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Option B:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs that promotes urinary glucose excretion, leading to lower blood sugar levels. It has the following advantages in this patient's case:

 

  • Low risk of hypoglycemia: SGLT2 inhibitors do not cause hypoglycemia, which is a significant concern for this patient.
  • Weight loss: Empagliflozin can promote modest weight loss, addressing the patient's concern about weight gain.
  • Cardiovascular benefit: SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce cardiovascular mortality and morbidity in patients with T2DM and established CVD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: This is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) associated with weight gain and fluid retention, which would be undesirable for this patient.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor that may not provide sufficient glycemic control and does not have the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Option D. Insulin glargine: Insulin therapy is a potential option, but it carries a higher risk of hypoglycemia control and does not have the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin is suitable for patients with T2DM and cardiovascular disease as it reduces CV mortality, causes weight loss, and has a low risk of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and a history of MEN2A is considering starting a new anti-diabetic medication. Which of the following should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liraglutide

 

Option D:

 

Liraglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, has been associated with an increased risk of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) and pancreatic cancer in preclinical and observational studies. While the clinical significance of these findings remains unclear, caution is warranted in patients with MEN2A, who already have an increased risk of MTC and other endocrine tumors. Therefore, it's generally recommended to avoid liraglutide and other GLP-1 receptor agonists in this population.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: This is a first-line medication for type 2 diabetes and has not been associated with increased cancer risk.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This is a thiazolidinedione that has been associated with a potential increased risk of bladder cancer and a possible increased risk of breast cancer in some studies. However, it is not specifically linked to the cancers associated with MEN2A.

 

Option C. Empagliflozin: This is an SGLT2 inhibitor and has not been linked to increased cancer risk in MEN2A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide in patients with MEN2A due to the increased risk of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with a history of long-standing poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with blurred vision. On examination, there is severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) with macular edema. Which of the following drugs will be the best in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dulaglutide

 

Option B:

 

Dulaglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 RA). GLP-1 RAs have been shown to improve glycemic control and reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with type 2 diabetes. Additionally, they have been found to have a potential protective effect on diabetic retinopathy, including macular edema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that can improve glycemic control but can worsen diabetic retinopathy and macular edema.

 

Option C. Semaglutide: Another GLP-1 RA, that gives good glycemic control but studies indicate increased risk of worsening diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Exenatide: Another GLP-1 RA, that gives good glycemic control but studies indicate increased risk of worsening diabetic retinopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dulaglutide is the preferred GLP-1 receptor agonist for patients with severe NPDR and macular edema due to its potential protective effect on diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with long-standing type 2 diabetes and ESRD (end-stage renal disease). His eGFR is 8 mL/min/1.73 m², and he is currently non-oliguric. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glibenclamide

 

Option D:

 

Glbenclamide (Glyburide) has a long half-life and is primarily excreted by the kidneys. It can accumulate in patients with ESRD, increasing the risk of prolonged and severe hypoglycemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone (TZD): Not excreted by kidneys, so can be safely used in CKD (at any stage). But cautious use is warranted in view of fluid retention and bone loss which can complicate volume overload state and renal osteodystrophy in ESRD patients.

 

Option B. Semaglutide: This GLP-1 receptor agonist can be used safely in CKD (at any stage) without doe adjustment.

 

Option C. Repaglinide: This meglitinide has a short half-life and is primarily metabolized by the liver, making it a safer option for patients with renal impairment.

 

Drugs that can be used without dose adjustment in ESRD (eGFR < 15) - Linagliptin, Liraglutide (but caution), dulaglutide, semaglutide, repaglinide, glipizide (start slowly and titrate) and Pioglitazone/Rosiglitazone.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid Glibenclamide in patients with ESRD due to the risk of prolonged and severe hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with newly diagnosed diabetes has an HbA1c of 7%. What is the major contributor to his current HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postprandial blood sugar

 

Option B:

 

HbA1c reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months. While both fasting and postprandial blood sugar contribute to HbA1c, postprandial blood sugar (blood sugar levels after meals) typically has a greater impact on overall glycemic control and HbA1c levels in individuals with lower HbA1C (especially if HbA1C is < 7.3%).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fasting blood sugar: Contribution to HbA1C becomes significant at higher HbA1C (especially if HbA1C is > 9.2%)

 

Option C. Both A and C: At HbA1C of 7.3-9.2% the contribution by Fasting and Post prandial sugars are roughly equivalent.

 

Option D. Serum albumin levels: Its levels do not influence HbA1c (rather it influences levels of fructosamine and glycated albumin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with lower HbA1c levels (<7.3%), postprandial blood sugar has a greater impact on overall glycemic control and HbA1c levels.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with type 2 diabetes presents with newly diagnosed bladder cancer. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapagliflozin

 

Option B:

 

Recent studies have suggested a potential association between the use of SGLT2 inhibitors, such as dapagliflozin, and an increased risk of bladder cancer. While the evidence is not definitive, it is generally recommended to use caution or avoid these drugs in patients with a history of bladder cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glibenclamide (a sulfonylurea): There is no established link between sulfonylureas and bladder cancer risk.

 

Option C. Liraglutide (a GLP-1 receptor agonist): GLP-1 receptor agonists have not been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Pramlintide (an amylin analog): Pramlintide has not been linked to any increased cancer risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid Dapagliflozin in patients with a history of bladder cancer due to the potential association with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding the effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduces glucagon release

 

Option C:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors do not reduce glucagon release; in fact, they can increase glucagon levels (because of their glucose lowering effect). This increase in glucagon can contribute to euglycemic DKA, especially in conditions of stress or illness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reduction in CV mortality: SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce cardiovascular mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes, especially those with established cardiovascular disease.

 

Option B. Can cause euglycemic ketoacidosis: This is a known side effect of SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Option D. Can cause hypotension: SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild to moderate hypotension due to their diuretic effect. They can reduce SBP by ∼ 3-6 mm Hg on average.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors do not reduce glucagon release; they can actually increase glucagon levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the longest-acting basal insulin analog?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Icodec

 

Option B:

 

Insulin icodec is an ultra-long-acting basal insulin analog with a duration of action exceeding 42 hours, allowing for flexible dosing regimens (once weekly or every other week).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glargine: While glargine is a long-acting insulin, its duration of action is around 24 hours.

 

Option C. Degludec: This is another long-acting insulin with a duration of action exceeding 42 hours, but not as long as icodec.

 

Option D. Detemir: Detemir is a long-acting insulin with a duration of action of around 20-24 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin icodec is an ultra-long-acting basal insulin analog with a duration of action exceeding 42 hours.

questions.text: A 54-year-old obese female with type 2 diabetes for 10 years came for a master health check-up. Routine USG revealed gallstones, and her triglyceride levels are 1620 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liraglutide

 

Option A:

 

Liraglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, has been associated with an increased risk of gallstones and pancreatitis, especially in patients with pre-existing gallbladder disease or high triglyceride (TG) levels. Given the patient's gallstones and significantly elevated triglycerides (1620 mg/dL), liraglutide should be avoided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor): Not associated with an increased risk of gallstones or pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone (thiazolidinedione): Not known to directly increase gallstone or pancreatitis risk. Pioglitazone can reduce TG and increase HDL (but it can slightly increase LDL as well).

 

Option D. Metformin (biguanide): Not associated with an increased risk of gallstones or pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid liraglutide in patients with gallstones and significantly elevated triglycerides due to the risk of gallstones and pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c 9.1%) is already on metformin, empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor), and sitagliptin (DPP-4 inhibitor). He has well-controlled dyslipidemia and hypertension with telmisartan and rosuvastatin. Which medication would be the most appropriate next step to improve glycemic control?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Semaglutide

 

Option A:

 

Given the patient's history of poorly controlled diabetes despite multiple oral agents and the presence of multiple cardiovascular risk factors, a GLP-1 receptor agonist like semaglutide is the most appropriate next step. GLP-1 RAs have been shown to improve glycemic control, promote weight loss, and, importantly, reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease.

 

In most patients, the first line injectable in current practice is GLP1RA (except for those who are having severe/symptomatic hyperglycemia where insulin can be preferred ahead of GLP1RA).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: This is a sulfonylurea, which carries a risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain. It does not offer the same cardiovascular benefits as semaglutide.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone: This is a thiazolidinedione associated with weight gain and fluid retention, which could be problematic for this patient.

 

Option D. Insulin glargine: While insulin can improve glycemic control, it does not address the cardiovascular risk factors and carries a risk of hypoglycemia. Additionally, the patient may prefer a non-injectable option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Semaglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that improves glycemic control, promotes weight loss, and reduces cardiovascular risk in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Strict glycemic control in Type 2 Diabetes can reduce all the complications except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD)

 

Option B:

 

While strict glycemic control is crucial in managing type 2 diabetes and reducing the risk of microvascular complications like retinopathy, neuropathy, and nephropathy, its impact on macrovascular complications like peripheral artery disease (PAD) is less clear. PAD is primarily driven by atherosclerosis, which is influenced by multiple factors including hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and smoking. While good glycemic control can help reduce the risk of PAD, it is not the sole determinant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retinopathy: Strict glycemic control has been proven to significantly reduce the risk and progression of diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option C. Neuropathy: Tight glucose control can slow the onset and progression of diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option D. Nephropathy: Maintaining optimal blood glucose levels is crucial in preventing and delaying the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strict glycemic control reduces microvascular complications (retinopathy, neuropathy, nephropathy) but has less clear impact on macrovascular complications like PAD.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman who was a known diabetic and hypertensive presented with angioedema. Which of the following drugs could be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Linagliptin

 

Option B:

 

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors have been associated with an increased risk of angioedema, particularly in patients also taking ACE inhibitors (a common class of blood pressure medication).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: This is a biguanide used to treat type 2 diabetes and is not associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone: This is a thiazolidinedione used to treat type 2 diabetes and is not associated with angioedema.

 

Option D. Chlorthalidone: This is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension and is not known to cause angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, can cause angioedema, particularly in patients also taking ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with newly diagnosed diabetes and an HbA1c of 8%. He has a history of sulfa allergy since childhood. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glimepiride

 

Option A:

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that are chemically similar to sulfonamides (sulfa drugs). Patients with a known sulfa allergy may also be allergic to sulfonylureas and could experience a cross-reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor and is not structurally related to sulfa drugs.

 

Option C. Liraglutide: This is a GLP-1 receptor agonist and is not structurally related to sulfa drugs.

 

Option D. Acarbose: This is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor and is not structurally related to sulfa drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid sulfonylureas like glimepiride in patients with a known sulfa allergy due to the risk of cross-reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommended glycemic target in critically ill patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 140-180 mg/dL

 

Option A:

 

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends a target blood glucose range of 140-180 mg/dL for most critically ill patients. This range is a balance between avoiding hypoglycemia (which can be dangerous in critically ill patients) and preventing the complications of hyperglycemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 80-180 mg/dL: This range is too narrow and may be difficult to achieve without increasing the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. 81-108 mg/dL: NICE-SUGAR study found increased mortality in critically ill patients when this target is followed. Hence, it is not recommended.

 

Option D. 150-200 mg/dL: This is not a recommended target in hospitalized patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended glycemic target in critically ill patients is 140-180 mg/dL to balance the risk of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia complications.

choices.text: Metformin is not FDA approved for GDM
Strict control of glucose is required
High risk of neonatal hyperglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding diabetes in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High risk of neonatal hyperglycemia

 

Option D:

 

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is characterized by high blood glucose levels during pregnancy. It can lead to fetal hyperinsulinemia as the fetus is exposed to high maternal glucose levels, stimulating insulin production. This can result in neonatal hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) after birth, not hyperglycemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fetal hyperinsulinemia: This is true. High maternal glucose levels can lead to increased insulin production in the fetus.

 

Option B. Metformin is not FDA approved for GDM: This is true. While metformin is increasingly used off-label for GDM, it is not currently FDA-approved for this indication.

 

Option C. Strict control of glucose is required: This is true. Maintaining tight glycemic control during pregnancy is crucial for preventing complications in both the mother and the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GDM can lead to fetal hyperinsulinemia and neonatal hypoglycemia, not hyperglycemia.
